channel.title: Network SAM?
channel.description: Today at school I attempted to capture a SAM file (wndows password file) on one of their many computers in the network. When I decrypted the SAM File at home I discovered none of the 200+ users were in this file. Is it possible that there is some sort of SAM File in another directory on the computer or on the network. If so, where? Also, I cant do anything major because I'm have a limited user account.

item.title: Network SAM?
item.dc:creator: @therealjdb JDB`
item.description:
@therealjdb wrote:

[quote=“The Un-Named, post:9, topic:67843”][quote author=therealjdb link=topic=99196.msg1013655#msg1013655 date=1173933877]

because it wouldn’t make much sense to add a whole schools worth of logins to each computer.

My old school teacher believed in open source software and Linux, he was so confident he didn’t give root a password and gave people the ability to do sudo in the terminal. I wish I still went there, I was a noob then but meh.

rofl, I wish that my teachers were that dumb, well I suppose they are. The guest account at my school is whguest (West High) and the password is 12345. I was just messing around and all the sudden it logged me in, the guest has more privileges than a regular student though.
[/quote]

He wasn’t dumb, actually, the linux machines had multiple desktop sessions to choose from, and everyone didn’t know shit about linux pc’s so they couldn’t do much. The PC’s logged what user logs in and what it does in key places so he would know anyway.[/quote]
Yeah, dumb wasn’t the word I was really looking for it just came to mind, lol sorry if I offended you. :o

Read full topic

because it wouldn’t make much sense to add a whole schools worth of logins to each computer.

My old school teacher believed in open source software and Linux, he was so confident he didn’t give root a password and gave people the ability to do sudo in the terminal. I wish I still went there, I was a noob then but meh.
[/quote]
rofl, I wish that my teachers were that dumb, well I suppose they are. The guest account at my school is whguest (West High) and the password is 12345. I was just messing around and all the sudden it logged me in, the guest has more privileges than a regular student though.[/quote]

He wasn’t dumb, actually, the linux machines had multiple desktop sessions to choose from, and everyone didn’t know shit about linux pc’s so they couldn’t do much. The PC’s logged what user logs in and what it does in key places so he would know anyway.

Read full topic

item.title: Network SAM?
item.dc:creator: @xxlegitxx xxlegitxx
item.description:
@xxlegitxx wrote:

So how would I go about accessing this C:\WINDOWS\system32\config\SAM file?

Read full topic

item.title: Network SAM?
item.dc:creator: @therealjdb JDB`
item.description:
@therealjdb wrote:

xxlegitxx:

Wtf, where do you find a sam file?

It can be found on the hard drive in the folder %systemroot%system32config. However this folder is locked to all accounts including Administrator while the machine is running. The only account that can access the SAM file during operation is the “System” account.

Read full topic

item.title: Network SAM?
item.dc:creator: @therealjdb JDB`
item.description:
@therealjdb wrote:

Well the way my school’s computers are set up the SAM file would be of no use for getting into anything besides one of the many workstations. Each individual has there own HD partition on the network and that is accessed remotely. I assume that your computers there would be similar because it wouldn’t make much sense to add a whole schools worth of logins to each computer. The SAM file would only benefit you if you wanted to login to the certain workstation.

Read full topic

@gikid wrote:

Today at school I attempted to capture a SAM file (wndows password file) on one of their many computers in the network. When I decrypted the SAM File at home I discovered none of the 200+ users were in this file. Is it possible that there is some sort of SAM File in another directory on the computer or on the network. If so, where? Also, I cant do anything major because I’m have a limited user account.

Read full topic
